Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 06:31PM momo3esb wrote: Hi Erica, I am going in tomorrow to get the results of the excisional biopsy I had done on my lump that I found back in Dec. I know what you are going through since my core biopsy was initially benign.....but they wanted to remove it since it was still a "concerning" lump.  I would have to agree with what Deanna said above about finding out if they can schedule the appts together for you since you have a long drive AND especially her comment about bringing someone with you!  When I received my results from the core biopsy, I heard the benign but "concerning" and then promptly forgot everything from that point on!  It is really hard to concentrate on what they are saying (even though they know that and take their time and ask if you have any questions....etc) BUT having someone else there will help you remember afterwards what they said.  It may also help if you go over what your questions are with the person going with you so they are sure to ask those for you if you forget to ask them! I am hoping to have my husband take care of asking/remembering answers tomorrow when we get the results.  Better yet, I hope that there is no need since it will be benign!  However, I know my mind may still shut down even then and I won't hear what the heck the bugger was that was in me and I may not ever know!!!  I'll have to make sure to ask for a copy of the pathology report!!! Take care and keep in touch!  We started this trek at the same time ~ hopefully it will end at the same time and place.....benign!
Posts.Title: Appt at comprehensive breast clinic... What to ask? ecm kayakgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 05:22PM momo3esb wrote: Hi Bev, I know how you feel since I have been going through this same thing since Dec (although I don't have the family history to deal with!).  I found the lump in Dec ~ had to wait until Jan for the mammo and u/s.  I had those, met with the surgeon who said that a biopsy was needed ~ but if it was benign the lump could stay in since it would be unnecessary to scar up the breast.  After the benign core biopsy, the surgeon said that they didn't really trust the results, so they wanted to remove the lump to make sure that it really was benign.......so here I go again!!!!  So on March 2nd I had the excisional biopsy and had the 5cm lump removed.   It was found to be an intraductal papilloma and the doctor was overjoyed!!!  I didn't realize how worried he was that he would have to tell me that it was cancer! I do also have "fibrocystic breast disease" and what that is going to mean for my diagnostic future I am not sure.  I do have to go back in 6 weeks for another u/s to "make sure all is well" ~ not quite sure what he meant by that.....will have to clarify what he meant when I see him.  I have asked if it will grow back and he said "it shouldn't".  I have an "itchy breast" but no discharge at all.  So, we wait again to see where we go from here, BUT I and my family are truly breathing a sigh of relief for the first time since December! I hope that you can feel that this is really good news and not let it worry you too much.  Does it mean that you will never get cancer......no one can say that, but for this moment you are okay!  Take care! Kelly
Posts.Title: papilloma, Ok ,whats Next,? Stumped barbe1958

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 03:16PM momo3esb wrote: Thank you Beesie Kelly
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 07:14PM - edited Apr 8, 2009 07:15PM by momo3esb I am by no means a medical expert or claim to be one, but when I started on this journey I began a deal of research.  I agree with Beesie that the sentinel node is the first in a string of lymph nodes that are often biopsied in order to prevent the need to take a great deal of nodes.  If this node comes back clean, then the need to remove a large number of nodes is not there.  If the node is not clean, then more nodes need to be removed.  This was a big breakthrough since it is not in the best interest of women to remove large numbers of lymph nodes.   BTW, I found this information in many places, one of which was Susan Love's Breast Book. I also found the same info when I was researching my surgeon, who was one of the first in my area to do Sentinel node biopsies. Just my opinion (but based on much research...) Kelly

Posts.Title: I'll know tomorrow afternoon SisterPeace Lories

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 09:32PM momo3esb wrote: Dear Kathy, As all of the other wonderful women have said here, I too am sorry that you have to deal with this on top of having to deal with the too recent loss of your husband.  I also want to reassure you that I have been here on this discussion board for sometime and that I have seen a great deal of women who have been told by a doctor/radiologist that they definitely have cancer come back on one month or so later with benign results.  So, I know it is hard, but please try to relax a little bit and wait until you have had a biopsy before making ANY decisions ~ especially about having a breast removed.   Also, don't freak out about being referred to a surgeon right away.  I found my lump in December and my GP immediately referred me to a surgeon ~ my appointment was scheduled for the day after my mammo and u/s.  This was done before she even knew I would need to have a biopsy done.  I was actually glad that she was willing to turn my case over to someone who had more experience dealing with a possible case of cancer than she had.  I also had an incredibly long wait.....not for the appointment with the surgeon, but for the mammo and u/s!  I had to wait for a month, and then once it was decided that I needed to have the core biopsy I had to wait yet again!  Once those results came back (benign ~ but concerning?) I had to have an excisional biopsy and had to wait AGAIN!!!!!  Don't they realize what they are doing to us??????  But, I was able to stay somewhat sane by coming on here and trying to help others and venting when needed!  I also knew that I wasn't alone....... My results did come back benign again.....a intraductal papilloma and fibrocystic breast disease. I have to have another u/s in a couple of weeks and I am not sure where we go from there.  I will always feel scared and wonder if they "other shoe will fall", but I know where I can go for help and support. We are here for you and please try to relax a little and know you are NOT ALONE and we are all praying and thinking of you! Kelly
Posts.Title: just feeling all alone Kathyi6re desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 12:23PM momo3esb wrote: Hi Since it is benign and you are so young, you do have the option of leaving it in.  I just had a lump removed, but they weren't sure that it was benign despite the first biopsy results.  I do have some pain (although it is just about a week and a half since it was removed) but I am also done with breast feeding so I didn't worry about that at all (I am 43).  I would check to see if removal would have any impact on future breast feeding at all.  You may think at this point that you don't want to (or maybe you already know you do) but don't make that decision right now.  You may change your mind when you get pregnant....so make sure that any decision you make now doesn't take that choice away from you in the future! Good luck! Kelly
Posts.Title: To get surgery or not karissaerin dmayes

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 05:50PM momo3esb wrote: Hi mandymonkey, I found a lump in December that was finally removed in March (talk about the waiting!!!).  It was smooth, but was also long and big.  It didn't move and for the most part didn't hurt (unless I messed with it too much).  I went through several cycles and it never changed.   I had a mammogram and ultrasound done and it came back as BI-RAD 4 (suspicious for malignancy).  I was preparing myself for the very real possibility that I was going to be diagnosed with cancer, and with the size of my lump (5 cm) I was pretty worried that it wouldn't be good. When the core biopsy results came back, they were "benign, but concerning".  WHAT??????? Are they kidding?  Who is running this show, a man?  They must be trying to KILL me!  My husband just recently told me that he wanted to punch the surgeon throughout this whole thing! He was so mad at the amount of waiting we were made to do!!!!  I, however, used that time to come to terms with the reality of the situation and to mull it over in my mind.  I also tried to find support here and realized that I could do it if I had to, I just was hoping it wouldn't be the Stage IV that I feared it would be! Well, after they took the lump out, I had to wait 10 days to go back for the final results.  On that day, a strange calm came over me (I really think God works when we need him to....) and I spent the day at peace.  We did get the results that we had hoped and prayed for and it turned out to be a benign intraductal papilloma.  Now, I just have a rather large scar on my breast, an area where I am visually missing tissue, but I am cancer free and thankful! Please, when you have the ultrasound and mammogram, listen to what they say, but if they tell you that it looks as if it is cancer, remember that many women have been told this and when the biopsy results come back they are benign!  I am not sure if they do this to make sure that we come back for the biopsy (like I saw suggested on a post earlier) or if they really aren't aware of the emotional trauma they are putting us through, or ~ God forbid ~ if they just don't care!  BE SURE TO HAVE A BIOPSY IF THAT IS WHAT THEY SUGGEST!  Don't ignore that advise just because a great deal of women here have told you positive stories ~ but you don't have to automatically assume it is going to be cancer either!!!!! Take care of yourself and your family and stay connected! Kelly

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 09:45AM - edited Mar 3, 2012 09:48AM by momo3esb Hi Greenshamrock, A few years back now I found a lump in the shower ( on the bottom part of the breast) and immediately called the doctor. I was a month away from my annual mammo, so I thought they might wait, but they didn't.... Roller coaster ride started immediately!! My lump hurt, didn't move and it was on the bottom... I was about 43.5. A core biopsy was done and it really looked like it was a cancerous lump... I was petrified! I opted to have it removed, and to my and the surgeon's surprise (and he is a top notch surgeon in my area... He really thought it was cancer) it was a fibroadenoma. I know you are worried, and frankly, since no one can predict the outcome, it is expected that you would be worried!! Just know that there is that chance that is just something "small". Good luck and no matter what the outcome you will find great support here!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 05:44AM momo3esb wrote: Hi Mom, I had a 5 cm lump removed 3 weeks ago that caused a little pain (not a great deal ~ although now that it is gone I realize how much it caused) and it was also categorized a BI-RAD 4 by the ultrasound and mammogram and it came back as a intraductal papilloma ~ which is benign.   I know that fear is going to be a constant companion no matter what you read, but please keep in mind that not all lumps are cancerous.  In fact, most are not!  I am 43 and I found this lump by accident in the shower, and all sorts of thoughts went through my mind!  I found the lump in Dec and it took until March 12 to get the final answer.  So I have spent a great deal of time thinking about what I would do if it was cancer.  I now have a plan in action should it ever happen  !  I do hope to never need it!!!! Good luck and keep us posted and I will be praying for you!! Kelly

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 08:24AM momo3esb wrote: I just had an excisional biopsy done yesterday and now am waiting again......!  This whole "journey" began for me on Dec. 18 when I found the lump in the shower.  I had to wait until Jan 19 for the mammo and u/s and had an appt with the surgeon on Jan 20th.  He scheduled a core biopsy on Jan 29th and then we waited for those results.  Luckily, that didn't take too long, only about 4 days. The results were benign but "concerning"? so he wanted to take out the lump anyway!   So had a needle guided biopsy yesterday (and now I am wondering if the "concerning" result was because they couldn't sample part of the lump since they had a heck of a time getting the needle into the "lesion" ~ as they liked to call it).  Now the waiting begins again.....BUT this time my doc is going to a conference and won't be back until my follow-up appt on MARCH 12th!!!!!  So this may drive me crazy!  The only thing that is going to keep me sane is that the initial results were benign, so I am hopeful that these will be too! I have been waiting since Dec to have this resolved and it is not fun.  Now I just have to wait another 9 days and hopefully it will be over, or I will at least know where I need to begin!  It is the uncertainty that has been bothering me ~ can I spend money on this or am I going to be out of work for awhile (I do have sick time, but still....) ~ can I plan to do this or am I going to be recovering from some sort of surgery?  What does the future hold?  At least now I know that I should have some answers in the next week and a half....I've waited two months, what is 9 more days....... Take care of yourselves in the meantime..... Kelly

Posts.Title: Worried and felling alone saintmelissa saintmelissa

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 07:42AM momo3esb wrote: Fulloflife ~ I agree with mawhinney.  I have been on this board since I found this website the beginning of January and I am amazed at how many people want to share the ugly......but there are those who want to give you the good as well   We don't want you to be scared about any procedure that you have to have....just remember that your experiences with this are just like your experiences with child birth.....your's alone!  Many women want to tell you about the "horror stories" regarding birthing their children ~ very rarely the wonderful experiences. Not that having a biopsy is going to be wonderful, but it shouldn't cause you pain during the procedure.  They have medication for that!  I had a core biopsy done at the end of February and they constantly asked me if I was comfortable.  I was a little freaked out about the tugging and pulling ~ but no pain.  They were willing and able to add more pain relief if I needed it.  I also had a needle guided excisional biopsy done on Monday and the insertion of the needle was again a little freaky due to the pulling and tugging.  They kept asking again (at a different hospital) if I was in pain and needed more medication.  So, unless you have truly horrible people taking care of you, their goal is your comfort ~ not causing you pain!  Let them know if you are hurting if they don't notice ~ they will help you out! Take care ~ and I will be thinking of you and hoping for benign results! Kelly
Posts.Title: micro calification Edelenbos fulloflife

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 02:46PM - edited Mar 28, 2009 02:49PM by momo3esb Hi Saint Melissa and By Grace, I have just recently gone through all of this.....found a lump in Dec, doc felt it too.  Had to have the mammo & us done (but couldn't get in until Jan) and then off to the surgeon.  He said that I needed a core biopsy, but it was most likely going to be benign, but even if it wasn't, we caught it early and should have good results (he is not one to give false reassurances).  Core biopsy came back benign, but surgeon didn't like results (!!!!!!!) and wanted to remove lump anyway (maybe we should have skipped core in the first place?).   Good news is that the excisional biopsy came back as an intraductal papilloma (and of course fibrocystic breast disease and hyperplasia of normal type).  Now I just have to go back in 4 weeks for another us to check the area out....... My EVER CAUTIOUS surgeon won't tell me that this thing won't grow back though.  So, will I be going through this again in a few years?  Quite possibly........I am quite happy with the fact that my doctor will not tell me something just to make me happy....but I don't like the idea that this is going to hanging over my head indefinitely!  Will the next time actually be something?  Obviously no one can tell you.....but it is a scary situation.  However, I refuse to live my life in fear.  I have been ALERTED now that this can happen, not that it necessarily will.  I found the lump by accident in the shower.....now I will be more diligent about really doing self-exams!   When I went for the mammo and us in Jan, my yearly exam was scheduled for a week later.  So, I do keep up for those exams.  I am pretty diligent about my health, so I do try to keep on top of testing.  I will try to lose the extra 10-15 pounds and exercise everyday (although I really think I need a few more hours in the day!!)   I am also trying to reduce stress.  Believe it or not, this really helps!  I know what you mean about feeling silly posting here when so many women here are dealing with the worst case scenario!  But it is reassuring to many newcomers to see that not all women who find a lump or have calcifications on their mammos have cancer!  Feeling that I can help out someone that is scared is somewhat comforting to me.  So, don't worry about posting here......your problems are not trivial and you may be helping to reduce the stresses of others!!! I too am praying for ALL of our sisters, whether their results come back benign or worse!!! Thanks for "listening"! Kelly
Posts.Title: Worried and felling alone saintmelissa saintmelissa

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 02:14PM momo3esb wrote: But Rose, don't forget.......it could be B9!!!!!!!!  I have been waiting since I found my lump on 12/18 in the shower on the day of the funeral for a co-worker who had died of this disease to find out what the results will be for me.  I have my biopsy on Thursday (1/29) and see the surgeon again on 2/3.  I have been reading these posts since I found the lump (and this wonderful site) and have seen many wonderful women come and go with B9 results and some come and stay with the sad news.  I try to remind myself each and every day that I will not know what will become of my until after the report comes in ~ and until then I have not been diagnosed with anything!!!  At this point I am still B9!!!!   Read and educate yourself to the fullest.....but don't scare yourself too much!!  You don't want to lose hope! There is soooooo much information to take in ~ different types of cancers, stages, etc, that I just want to be able to ask the right questions if I need to.  But I am still hopeful that all I will have to say is ~ Thank you so much! You are all in my thoughts and prayers at all times!  Take care and please take care of yourselves! Kelly
Posts.Title: How fast can a tumor grow? Rosekittyhawk jodyannie
